question1: What startup, acquired by Facebook for $1 billion in 2012, became the fourth most downloaded app in the 2010s and is known for the posting of pictures?

question2: What is the programming language developed by James Gosling at Sun Microsystems and named after the type of coffee from Indonesia?

question3: Pierre Omidyar founded which popular online auction company in 1995 out of San Jose, California?

question4: In 1999 Shigetaka Kurita invented what keyboard additions for cell phones that would eventually replace emoticons and even get their own movie?

question5: What word is often abbreviated as Fn on a keyboard?

question6: What popular operating system, launched in 1991, also has its own mascot, Tux the penguin?

question7: The first FDA-approved telemedicine robot that uses autonomous movement technology is the RP-VITA, from the Roomba-making firm that shares what name with a Will Smith movie.

question8: THINK was the company motto for more than 40 years, for the company often referred to as 'Big Blue'. What is this frequently-acronymed company?

question9: What delicious computer term did web browser programmer Lou Montulli coin to refer to information that is sent from the browser to the web server?

question10: Now appearing prophetic, what device was announced in 2007 with the following slogan? 'This is only the beginning.'

question11: Developed by Unimation, the Programmable Universal Manipulation Arm is also known by the much shorter name of what fierce animal?

question12: What is the 6-letter term for a group of computers that is networked together and used by hackers to steal information?

question13: A dude named Chip Morningstar received the first JSON message, a format derived from what core language repped by the 'JS'?

question14: In 2022, Credit Kudos, a credit evaluation tool for lenders based out of the UK, was purchased by what technology giant with a fruit-based name?

question15: Andy Rubin is known as one of the three founders of what massively popular cell phone operating system?

question16: What “A” antivirus software is a freeware solution available across multiple platforms, with an amoeba like orange “A” as a logo? It is also a pirate word meaning “Stop.”

question17: Doug Engelbart was the inventor of what computer accessory? The first one was made from wood.

question18: The four principle wireless encryption standards available at most access points are WPA, WPA2, WPA3, and which less-secure fourth option?

question19: In a 1987 film starring Peter Weller and Nancy Allen, the city of Detroit signs a deal with the company Omni Consumer Products to re-build parts of the city into a utopia and introduce a law enforcement robot ED-209. What is this film?

question20: What is the seven-letter branded software standard created by Apple that enables a car radio or touchscreen to be a display and a controller for an iOS device?

question21: What American tech company had a microprocessor facility in Costa Rica that at one time was responsible for 20% of Costa Rican exports and 5% of the country's GDP?

question22: What simulation video game franchise was originally developed by Will Wright and launched in 1989 for the Macintosh computer?

question23: Composed for solo guitar by Francisco Tárrega in 1902, 'Grand Valse' is used as the distinctive ringtone of what Nordic telecom?

question24: In 2005, Linus Torvalds created software for tracking changes on files in order to improve development of the Linux kernel. Since 2005, the open-source software has had Junio Hamano as the core maintainer. What is the three-letter name of this uber-popular software among developers?

question25: What Japanese-based conglomerate used 'That '70s Show' star Ashton Kutcher to promote its Coolpix digital camera in a 2009 commercial?

question26: Tony Stark tries on his magnanimous dude persona at the start of 'Captain America: Civil War' by funding all student projects at what New England school?

question27: Unicode, the standard for character encoding used to represent multilingual text as binary, is the successor of what US encoding standard?

question28: What company providing hosting for software development and distributed version control familiar to computer programmers is known for its iconic Octocat (part cat, part octopus) logo?

question29: A November 1998 article titled 'New CYBERSCAPE: Digital Assistants Get Sophisticated' was the first article in the New York Times's archive to use what now-ubiquitous word which, despite its name, does not necessarily refer to the IQ of a pocket computer?

question30: Your computer is switching to a different _____ when you receive an HTTP code 101. What word fills in the blank?

question31: Maker of devices such as Nintendo gaming consoles, iPhones, and Amazon Kindle, the Taiwanese manufacturer Hon Hai Technology Group is better known by what 'sly' name?

question32: What multinational technology and internet company, owner of Fitbit, launched its own Finance website in 2006, tracking stocks and earnings along with financial news?

question33: What company's mid 1960's 'Drafting System' is often considered a tipping point in revealing the benefits of computer-aided design (CAD)?

question34: Officially announced in February 2019, the 'Mate X' folding cell phone will be manufactured and sold by what electronics giant?
